template.name: Template Active OS Windows
template.description: Active OS Windows Custom: CPU Memory Physical and logical Disk Network Inventory

item.name: Operating System days from latest update installed
% Processor Time
item.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PercentProcessorTime from Win32_PerfformattedData_PerfOS_Processor where Name='_Total']

item_prototype.name: Used Disk {#LOGICAL_DISK} {#LOGICAL_DISK_VOLUME_NAME} bytes
item_prototype.params: last("wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Size from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}']")-last("wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeSpace from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}']")

item_prototype.name: Used Disk {#LOGICAL_DISK} {#LOGICAL_DISK_VOLUME_NAME} bytes 12h linear forecast shifted
Free disk {#LOGICAL_DISK} {#LOGICAL_DISK_VOLUME_NAME} bytes
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeSpace from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}']

item_prototype.name: Total Disk {#LOGICAL_DISK} {#LOGICAL_DISK_VOLUME_NAME} bytes
item_prototype.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Size from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}']

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeSpace from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}'].last()}<1G
trigger_prototype.name: Free disk space is less than 1Gb on volume {#LOGICAL_DISK} (Last: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1})

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeSpace from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}'].last()}<10G and {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeSpace from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}'].last()}>1G
trigger_prototype.name: Free disk space is less than 10Gb on volume {#LOGICAL_DISK} (Last: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1})

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeSpace from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}'].last()}<25G and {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreeSpace from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}'].last()}>10G
trigger_prototype.name: Free disk space is less than 25Gb on volume {#LOGICAL_DISK} (Last: {ITEM.LASTVALUE1})

item.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select Size from win32_logicaldisk where DeviceID='{#LOGICAL_DISK}']

item_prototype.name: Physical Disk {#PHYSICAL_DISK} Avg. Disk Read/sec
item_prototype.description:
perf_counter["\PhysicalDisk({#PHYSICAL_DISK})\Avg. Disk sec/Read"]
Счетчик производительности Avg. Disk sec/Read указывает среднее время считывания данных с диска в секундах. Среднее значение счетчика производительности Avg. Disk sec/Read не должно превышать 10 миллисекунд. Максимальное значение счетчика производительности Avg. Disk sec/Read не должно превышать 50 миллисекунд.

item_prototype.name: Physical Disk {#PHYSICAL_DISK} Avg. Disk Write/sec
item_prototype.description:
perf_counter["\PhysicalDisk({#PHYSICAL_DISK})\Avg. Disk sec/Write"]
Счетчик производительности Avg. Disk sec/Read указывает среднее время считывания данных с диска в секундах. Среднее значение счетчика производительности Avg. Disk sec/Read не должно превышать 10 миллисекунд. Максимальное значение счетчика производительности Avg. Disk sec/Read не должно превышать 50 миллисекунд.

item_prototype.name: Physical Disk {#PHYSICAL_DISK} Disk Read Bytes/sec
item_prototype.description:
perf_counter["\PhysicalDisk({#PHYSICAL_DISK})\Disk Read Bytes/sec"]
Средняя скорость обмена данными с диском, или скорость чтения\записи. Показывает общее количество байт, отправленных на диск (запись) и с диска (чтение) в течении одной секунды, тем самым позволяя оценить пропускную способность дисковой системы. Складывается из значений Disk Read Bytes/sec (скорость чтения) и Disk Write Bytes/sec (скорость записи). Предельные значения сильно зависят от типа диска: к примеру для одиночного жесткого диска максимальная скорость чтения\записи лежит в пределах 160-250Mb/s, для одиночного SSD — около 550-600Mb/s.

item_prototype.name: Physical Disk {#PHYSICAL_DISK} Disk Transfers/sec iops
item_prototype.description:
perf_counter["\PhysicalDisk({#PHYSICAL_DISK})\Disk Transfers/sec"]
Основной показатель интенсивности запросов к диску. Показывает общее количество операций ввода\вывода, обработанных (завершенных) диском в течении 1 секунды (Input/Output Operations Per Second, IOPS). Этот счетчик позволяет примерно оценить, насколько нагрузка на диски близка к предельной. Для дисков, работающих в нормальном режиме, можно ориентироваться на следующие значения: 80-160 IOPS для одиночного жесткого диска SATA или SAS, 1800-5000 IOPS для одиночного SSD диска. Для уточнения можно воспользоваться счетчиками Disk Reads/sec (количество обработанных за секунду запросов на чтение) и Disk Writes/sec (количество обработанных за секунду запросов на запись).

item_prototype.name: Physical Disk {#PHYSICAL_DISK} Disk Write Bytes/sec
item_prototype.description:
perf_counter["\PhysicalDisk({#PHYSICAL_DISK})\Disk Write Bytes/sec"]
Средняя скорость обмена данными с диском, или скорость чтения\записи. Показывает общее количество байт, отправленных на диск (запись) и с диска (чтение) в течении одной секунды, тем самым позволяя оценить пропускную способность дисковой системы. Складывается из значений Disk Read Bytes/sec (скорость чтения) и Disk Write Bytes/sec (скорость записи). Предельные значения сильно зависят от типа диска: к примеру для одиночного жесткого диска максимальная скорость чтения\записи лежит в пределах 160-250Mb/s, для одиночного SSD — около 550-600Mb/s.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select AvgDisksecPerRead from Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfDisk_PhysicalDisk where Name='{#PHYSICAL_DISK}'].avg(30m)}>0.25
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select AvgDisksecPerRead from Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfDisk_PhysicalDisk where Name='{#PHYSICAL_DISK}'].avg(30m)}<0.1
trigger_prototype.name: PhysicalDisk {#PHYSICAL_DISK} Avg. Disk sec/Read higher 0.25

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select AvgDisksecPerWrite from Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfDisk_PhysicalDisk where Name='{#PHYSICAL_DISK}'].avg(30m)}>0.25
trigger_prototype.recovery_expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select AvgDisksecPerWrite from Win32_PerfFormattedData_PerfDisk_PhysicalDisk where Name='{#PHYSICAL_DISK}'].avg(30m)}<0.1
trigger_prototype.name: PhysicalDisk {#PHYSICAL_DISK} Avg. Disk sec/Write higher 0.25

item_prototype.name: Network Interface {#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME} % Utilization
item_prototype.params: ( (last("wmi.get[root\cimv2,select BytesTotalPersec from Win32_PerfFormattedData_Tcpip_NetworkInterface where Name='{#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME_PERF}']") *8) / last("wmi.get[root\cimv2,select CurrentBandwidth from Win32_PerfFormattedData_Tcpip_NetworkInterface where Name='{#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME_PERF}']"))*100

item_prototype.name: Network Interface {#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME} Total Bytes/sec
item_prototype.description: last("perf_counter[\"\Network Interface({#PNETWORK})\Bytes Received/sec\"]")*(-1)+ last("perf_counter[\"\Network Interface({#PNETWORK})\Bytes Sent/sec\"]")

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select NetConnectionStatus from win32_networkadapter where InterfaceIndex='{#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_INTERFACEINDEX}'].diff(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: Network Interface {#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME} Link Status changed

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select MACAddress from win32_networkadapter where InterfaceIndex='{#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_INTERFACEINDEX}'].diff(0)}>0
trigger_prototype.name: Network Interface {#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME} MAC Address changed

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select OutputQueueLength from Win32_PerfFormattedData_Tcpip_NetworkInterface where Name='{#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME_PERF}'].last(#5)}>2
trigger_prototype.name: Network Interface {#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME} Output Queue Length > 2
trigger_prototype.description: Each Network Interface has an associated output queue. Output Queue Length measures how many outbound network packets are queued. Output Queue Length of 2 or more indicates serious Network Interface bottlenecks. When reviewing Output Queue Length, it is important to review the active Network Interface utilized.

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PacketsOutboundDiscarded from Win32_PerfFormattedData_Tcpip_NetworkInterface where Name='{#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME_PERF}'].last(#1)}>100
trigger_prototype.name: Network Interface {#PHYSICAL_NETWORK_NAME} Packets Outbound Discarded >100
trigger_prototype.description: A healthy Server deployment should not be consistently discarding network packets on a managed network. The threshold means that packets are being discarded and the server administrator should be aware and understand why that is occurring. If the Network Interface is too busy, requests may not be getting processed quickly enough and become discarded. It is important to note that these Performance Counters are total based. To get the value for review, you’ll need to subtract the maximum of the last sample from to the maximum of the first sample (we’ve done this for you in the Analysis and Definitions Workbook), leaving you with the delta of how many packets have been discarded during your data collection. If you see that the value is not zero, but is the same for average and max, it hasn’t moved in the dataset. Therefore, it could be contributed to a change in the environment that was expected (e.g. switch firmware ugrade) and be a non-issue. Depending on the Network Interface manufacture, the receive and transmit buffers may be configurable. If they are, set them to an automatic setting. Should that not be an option, consider doubling the current value and re-evaluate.

discovery_rule.name: Windows service discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of Windows services of different types as defined in global regular expressions "Windows service names for discovery" and "Windows service startup states for discovery".

trigger.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PercentProcessorTime from Win32_PerfformattedData_PerfOS_Processor where Name='_Total'].avg(1h)}>80
trigger.recovery_expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PercentProcessorTime from Win32_PerfformattedData_PerfOS_Processor where Name='_Total'].avg(1h)}<70
trigger.name: % Processor Time is 80% or higher
trigger.description: If % Processor Time is 80% or higher, the first path to explore is determining if there is a legitimate need to increase CPU capacity of your Lync Servers. Windows Server 2008 introduced new Power Management settings (which are on by default) to help reduce carbon footprint produced from Servers by consuming less electricity by parking CPU cores that are lightly utilized by moving those tasks to other cores. What this means is that high Processor Time values no longer automatically mean the physical CPUs are approaching their hardware limits

trigger.name: Firewall status has just been changed

trigger.expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreePhysicalMemory from Win32_OperatingSystem].avg(30m)}<1G
trigger.recovery_expression: {Template Active OS Windows:wmi.get[root\cimv2,select FreePhysicalMemory from Win32_OperatingSystem].avg(30m)}>1G
trigger.name: Memory Available Gb
trigger.description: Available Megabytes is different from most other KHIs in the regard that you need to pay attention to two things: • The trending direction is reversed (i.e. higher is better) • Track the minimum and average, not maximum. Most likely, the server doesn’t have enough RAM to fulfil demand. To verify, either use Task Manager and look for unaccounted processes or use the Private Bytes (in process counter object) to see identify the culprit. Lastly, if you discover SQL Server Express on Front-end Servers is the consumer of this memory verify that Lock Pages in Memory is disabled. When configured, Windows Memory Manager cannot trim SQL Servers Working Set for other processes while that memory is not in used.

trigger.name: Windows updates installed more than 90 days ago
Windows updates installed more than 180 days ago

item.key: wmi.get[root\cimv2,select PercentProcessorTime from Win32_PerfformattedData_PerfOS_Processor where Name='_Total']
